conclusion: To determine when objects A and B meet, analyze the velocity-time graphs and find where their positions become equal.
Both objects start at the same position.
Object A's velocity-time graph consists of straight line segments: from 0 to t₂, velocity increases linearly from 0 to v₀; from t₂ to t₄, velocity decreases linearly from v₀ to 0.
Object B's velocity-time graph consists of curved segments: from 0 to t₃, velocity decreases from v₀ toward 0 (exponential decay); from t₃ to t₄, velocity increases from near 0 back to v₀.
Position is the integral of velocity with respect to time, represented as the area under the velocity-time curve.

premise: Position is the integral of velocity with respect to time.
conclusion: The position of each object at any time t is equal to the area under its velocity-time curve from 0 to t.
The second image shows red horizontal lines representing equal time intervals.

premise: For the objects to meet, they must have traveled the same distance from their starting point.
conclusion: The areas under their respective velocity-time curves must be equal at the moment they meet.
Initially, object B has greater velocity than object A.

premise: Initially, object B has greater velocity than object A.
conclusion: Object B's position increases more rapidly at first.
At some point, object A's velocity exceeds object B's.

premise: At some point, object A's velocity exceeds object B's.
conclusion: Object A starts catching up to object B.

premise: Object A starts catching up to object B.
conclusion: Their positions become equal when the areas under their curves become equal.
Based on the red shading in the second image, the areas under both curves become equal at time t₄.

premise: The areas under both curves become equal at time t₄.
conclusion: The two objects meet at time t₄.
